Pearce of Rhode-Island moved a Call upon the President for enquiry concerning the claim of indemnity upon the Danish Government for the prizes taken during our Revolutionary War, sent into Norway and there delivered up to the British Consul— This Resolution is preparatory to the discussion of the claim of Janette Taylor— It lies over one day— Among many other Resolutions offered was one by Cambreleng instructing the Committee of Commerce to enquire in to the expediency of abolishing all Laws authorising protections to be issued to American Seamen— Some objection was made to this Resolution— I supported its reference to the Committee for enquiry, but expressed my doubts whether the issuing of protections ought to be superseded— I thought it might be very proper to grant them gratuitously, to relieve the Seaman from the Charge— There was some further debate, not against the reference to the Committee, but against the proposition to abolish the issuing of Protections altogether— Cushing moved an amendment restricting the enquiry to the abolition of the tax, and Gillett moved to enlarge it to the abolition of all fees imposed upon Seamen, which Cambreleng accepted as a Modification, and so the Resolution passed— The orders of the day, brought up Wise’s Resolution reported by the Committee of the whole on the Union, for a Committee of enquiry into the ability and integrity of the Executive Departments, with the substitute proposed as an Amendment by D. J. Pearce—but Wise the mover of the original Resolution was absent, and after some remarks by several members the further consideration was postponed till next Tuesday— A joint Resolution from the Senate concerning the printing of the Annual Report from the Treasury of the Commerce and Navigation of the United States was referred to the Committee of Commerce, and the Bill for reorganizing the Mint establishment was taken up in Committee of the whole on the Union— Harper’s motion to fix the weight of the cent at 168 grains Troy, as it has been these forty years, instead of 140 to which the Bill proposed to reduce it was pending, and I supported it very earnestly. The amendment was carried— I moved as a further amendment, that the dime, instead of 40 grains as proposed in the bill, should be fixed at 41 1/4 grains and the half dime at 20 5/8 instead of 20. these amendments after some discussion were assented
assented to by Cambreleng and adopted by the Committee, and thus the Bill was reported to the House, and passed to a third reading— Gillett proposed to restore a proviso that Cents should be made a tender at least to the amount of half a dime, but his motion was rejected— He did not attempt to introduce his one, two and three dollar gold coins— The House adjourned about 3. O’Clock— The young Ladies had been riding and were in waiting for me in the Carriage, but I walked home— Thomas J. Frye dined with us and Elizabeth De Wint was here after dinner— We had cards in the Evening.
28. V:30. Wednesday. Fahrenheit 10.

The coldest Night and morning of the present Season, and when I rose the fire in my chamber was extinct. I was obliged therefore to sit in the dining room below, and read some of the documents annexed to Mr Packer’s Report to the Senate of Pennsylvania on the subject of the Coal Trade— They are highly interesting, and contain a mass of valuable information upon the Pennsylvania Coal Mines— Among them I find a Statement by Mr. John White the person who gave me the pamphlet; and a paper altogether characteristic from my old friend Charles Miner.— There are conflicting statements in these papers concerning the expediency and usefulness of chartered companies for carrying on the coal trade— There is particularly a Lehigh Navigation and company incorporated to remove obstructions to the Navigation of the Lehigh river, and invested also with mining privileges— They have at immense expense removed the obstructions to the Navigation of the Lehigh, but they have become very obnoxious to the individual coal-miners by levying a toll, which makes competition with them in the trade impracticable— The individual miners, are violent adversaries therefore to the company—insisting that the river Lehigh is a highway, and that the Legislature had no constitutional right to grant the exclusive Navigation of it to a Corporation without a Soul— This is the Charles river Bridge question in another form— The doctrine of Mortmain is yet not well understood in this Country. At the House, I presented the Petition of Jerusha Ripley widow successively of Sturtevant, andRipley, both Soldiers of the Revolutionary War; she is of Plympton, blind, poor, and upwards of 80. years of age— Referred with two affidavits to support the facts stated in the petition to the Committee on Revolutionary Pensions— Numerous other Petitions were presented, and numerous reports of Committees, among which Howard, Chairman of the Committee of Foreign Relations, reported a Bill for carrying into effect the boundary Treaty between the United States and Mexico—read twice and referred to the Committee of the whole on the state of the Union— This Bill ought to have passed at the last Session of Congress; but it was set aside by the frenzy for the immediate recognition of Texas— Then came the Resolutions, of which I notice only those of chiefest interest— Gideon Lee moved an instruction to enquire by the Committee of Post Offices and Post-roads into the necessity of procuring a fire proof Post-Office building at the City of New York— And Gideon said he knew it was not
not proper in offering such a Resolution to make a speech and he made a Speech— His Resolution was adopted— Vanderpoel moved an instruction to the Committee of Foreign Relations, to inquire into the expediency of abolishing the Office of Agents of Claims at Paris and London— And he made an unanswered Speech, and his Resolution was adopted— Taylor of New-York moved an instruction to the Committee on Revolutionary Pensions, to inquire into the expediency of extending the Pension act of the 4th. of July last, in behalf of widows, to the widows of all Revolutionary Soldiers who ought to have been pensioned, excepting such as were remarried after the War—and Taylor made a well written and ornamented, and gallant Speech—and his Resolution was adopted— Hard of New-York moved an instruction of enquiry, to grant lands to the officers in the last War— But this Resolution after some debate was laid on the Table by yeas and nays 121 to 70.— Gillett of New-York moved an instruction to the Committee on the Judiciary, to inquire into the expediency of establishing a board of claims; and Howard moved an inquiry by the Committee of Naval Affairs for the establishment of a Naval Academy. A Report from the Postmaster General was received with an estimate of the sums required for the service of that Department in the year 1837. amounting to four Millions and a half of dollars, three millions and two hundred thousand dollars for transportation of the Mail, 935000 dollars for compensation of Postmasters and 140000 dollars for Clerks— The Mint Bill was read a third time and passed—and two Bills of Appropriations—one of two Millions for suppression of Indian hostilities, and one for the payment of Pensioners; both passed without question or one word of debate— Amendments were made by unanimous consent to the mint Bill; rendered necessary by the amendments adopted yesterday, but which had not then been attended to; because I suffered the question to be taken on the whole remnant of the Bill, after obtaining the amendments for which I contended, without insisting that it should be read through Section by Section. Cambreleng came to my Seat this morning and shewed me that these amendments were necessary— One of them was a Section (the 38th) requiring the Director of the Mint to account for the profits made upon the debasement of the dimes— This Section was annulled by the amendment restoring the dime and half dime to their intrinsic value— Yet the section remained in the Bill till now stricken out— The Rules were suspended to resume the Call by States for Resolutions— Garland of Virginia moved a call upon the Secretary of the Treasury, for a return of profits and dividends made by the Deposit Banks, before and since their having the deposits— Garland is a stiff Van-Burenite; but has a Virginian propensity to bait the Executive— The Dutchmen did not dare to oppose his Resolution in front— So Gillett moved an amendment to call for a return of the increased expenses of the deposit Banks— Boon of Indiana somewhat alarmed talked of moving a postponement, if there was a debate— Harlan of Kentucky moved as an amendment to Gillett’s amendment, that the Secretary should also return whether, a part of a those expenses of the Deposit Banks was for an Agent, in connection with the Treasury— The name of such agent, and the amount paid him
him by those Banks respectively— Reuben was about to be exposed, bare to the bone—Hannegan of Indiana instantly moved to lay the Resolution on the Table, and Boon, in agony moved to adjourn; which was carried— The young Ladies had been in the Gallery with Thomas J. Frye, who walked home with me; dined with us and went in the Evening to the Theatre— S. A. Elliot was here this Evening; but I did not incline to withdraw from Robert R. Livingston the credit I had given him in the Eulogy on Madison. Elliot, who is a Clerk in the War Department, talks of retiring from it; but has probly just apprehensions of being dismissed if he does not retire.
29. VI:30. Thursday.— Fahrenheit 14.

Morning visit from Dr. Kent the Senator from Maryland— At this time, since the decease of Robert H. Goldsborough, during the recess of Congress, the only one—with Isaac Munro the editor of the Baltimore Patriot; and a young man named Pettigrew, from North-Carolina— This visit belated me, full half an hour at the meeting of the Committee of Manufactures— I found there Denny, Gideon Lee, M’Comas, Granger, Bynum, Fowler, and T. T. Whittlesey. The only member absent was Taylor Webster.— Two subjects had been referred by the House to the Committee Since their last Meeting— A Petition from Evariste Maury, for compensation for his services in introducing into the United States the culture of Silk— Maury is a Frenchman, and has been nearly twenty years in this country; labouring to introduce the culture both of silk and the vine, with little success. His petition was in a jargon, half French, half English which the members of the Committee could not understand; and they were not prepared to admit even his claim of merit, as the first promoter of the culture of Silk in the United States— I mentioned the circular of enquiries from Mr Judson, with the answers by Mr Chew of Ohio, transmitted to me, by Mr M’Lane, a member from that State; but I had not the paper with me— So the further consideration of the subject was postponed, and I was directed to write to Mr Judson, for information of his proceedings under the authority with which he was charged by the Committee at the last Session— The other subject referred to the Committee was a petition from sundry Citizens of Philadelphia manufacturers of Starch, for the imposition of a duty upon the importation of that Article from abroad—which for want of time to discuss was also postponed to the next Meeting this day week— At the House, the day was wasted in a debate upon a motion made by Galbraith of Pennsylvania, to refer to a Select Committee a Memorial from sundry of his Constituents, called up from the files of the last Session urging upon Congress to propose an Amendment to the Constitution, restricting the States from the power of chartering Banks; and also complaining that the Bank of the United States, have continued to reissue their old Notes, since the expiration of their Charter granted by Congress, and calling upon that body to provide
provide a remedy for this evil— Galbraith moved to refer this Memorial to a select Committee; which engaged a very gratuitous debate of three hours— Levi Lincoln, made a warm, passionate, and not very forcible Speech against it, thereby rallying all the administration strength in support of Galbraith’s motion, which otherwise might have failed— Lincoln moved the reference to the Committee already appointed upon other proposed Amendments to the Constitution— D. J. Pearce moved the reference to the Committee of Ways and Means— Hannegan, getting tired of a senseless debate moved the Previous Question which was carried, and the reference was made to a select Committee— Two or three Executive Communications were received, and the House adjourned soon after 3.— Mr Lay of New-York, and Mr Cary a member of the Senate of that State paid us evening visits, and Mr Lay, joined in the party of our Ladies at Whist.
30. VI:30. Friday.

Benumbed fingers and no diary this morning. At the House Jesse Speight of North-Carolina, made his first appearance in the House for this Session— The Speaker laid before the House a Message from the President, in answer to a call moved last week by Mr Chapin of New-York for information of what had been done since the act of the last Session of Congress, relating to the bequest of James Smithson—the Message communicated a Report from the Secretary of State, with two Letters from Richard Rush, appointed the Agent under the Act of the last Session to obtain the property left by the Testator from the English Court of Chancery— The Letters merely announce the arrival of Mr Rush in England—and a first interview with the Chancery Lawyers—in which he made no progress whatever— Those Chancery Lawyers are exceedingly respectable persons, and I have no doubt will secure to themselves a good portion of the bequest. How much we shall ever get of it is exceedingly problematical— The States and Territories were called through for petitions and memorials, many of which were presented— Among the Reports of Committees, was one from Wardwell Chairman of the Committee on Revolutionary Pensions, of a Bill, extending the Provisions of the Pension Act of June 1832. He reported also against a proposed Resolution referred to the Committee, for extending the provisions of the act of 4. July last 3d. Section, so as to allow half pension to all widows of revolutionary pensioners. The Resolution was offered on the 12th instt. by Horace Everett, of Vermont— D. J. Pearce from the Committee of Commerce reported a Bill to change the name of the collection District of Dighton, Massachusetts, to Fall river, which was read twice and ordered to be engrossed for a third reading to-morrow— I proposed to Pearce, to offer an amendment to the Bill, making Wareham, a Collection district separate from New-Bedford; which provision is already in a Bill reported by the Committee of Commerce, at the last Session of Congress; but which I fear will not be reached for discussion. Pearce urged me not to offer it now, fearing that it might lead to debate upon the Bill this day reported, and perhaps defeat its passage; and he promised to call up the other Bill as soon as possible
possible.— Lewis Williams by a suspension of the Rules 154 to 38 offered a Resolution instructing the Committee of Public Lands to enquire into the expediency of prohibiting by Law the purchase of Lands at auction with a view to forfeit them, and afterwards obtain them at Government price of one dollar and 25 Cents per Acre— Lane moved as an amendment the reference to a select Committee, with additional instructions for confining all Sales of Public Lands to actual Settlers. Lane’s amendment was ferociously resisted by Boon and Dunlap, and he withdrew it—upon which Williams’s Resolution was adopted— Vanderpoel made an effort to offer a Resolution for adjourning over to Monday, but failed of obtaining two thirds to suspend the rules— Harlan was more successful with a Resolution to adjourn over from to-morrow till Tuesday— The Cold weather benumbs my fingers; but I did write this Evening to Benjamin Lundy; and in behalf of Mrs Tudor to the Secretary of State, Forsyth

31. VI:30. Saturday— Fahrenheit 14— The temperature of the atmosphere still disqualifies me for writing in the morning, and for keeping up with the course of time in my Diary, and compels me therefore to abridge.— At the House; after the presentation of Petitions, Horace Everett moved the suspension of the Rules that he might offer a Resolution of Instruction to the Committee of Public Lands to enquire into the expediency of prohibiting the Registers and Receivers of the Land Offices from purchasing public Lands for themselves or for others—but the House were not in a complying disposition, and he withdrew his motion— James Garland’s Resolution of enquiry for the dividends and profits of the deposite banks before and after they were entrusted with the public monies—was then taken up— Harlan had moved an amendment of enquiry, whether the Banks employed an agent in their dealings with the Treasury, with the name and compensation of the agent— Upon this Vanderpoel had shingled over another amendment of enquiry whether the Secretary of the Treasury employed any agent in his transactions with the Banks— Hannegan had made a motion to lay the whole on the table; which motion was now rejected by yeas and nays 28 to 141— Cushman moved the Previous question, which was rejected 78 to 91— It was clear that a decided majority of the House had made up their minds to allow the enquiry to be instituted— Harlan made a short Speech which hazarded his amendment; but Granger called for the yeas and nays, and Garland accepted the amendment of Harlan, and modified his Resolution so as to institute a select Committee of investigation, with power to send for persons and papers if they should think it necessary— D. J. Pearce opposed the Resolution, and E. Whittlesey suspended the debate by calling for the orders of the day— Thompson of Ohio, by a suspension of
of the Rules, obtained the use of the Hall for one hour from ten O’Clock next Tuesday morning, for an exhibition of the pupils of the New-England Asylum for the blind, under the direction of Dr S. G. Howe— And after some discussion of private Bills between 3 and 4. O’Clock the House adjourned— Evening party at Mr Frye’s— I went with Mary, and Elizabeth C. Adams Mr and Mrs W. S. Smith and Elizabeth De Wint was there— My wife not being very well, did not go—we spent the Evening at Cards, and had a gastronomic oyster supper— It was past eleven when we came home— It was not thus that I should have closed the year.

Day— Since the commencement of the Session of Congress, until the severe cold weather came on, I rose soon after four, sometimes earlier, and wrote till Sunrise, which according to the American Almanack, is now at the Solstice at 19. minutes past 7. O’Clock— I then hear my two Grand-daughters read— Mary Louisa one or two chapters in the Apocrypha— Both of them two Chapters in the New Testament— Between nine and ten we breakfast; after which the children now go to school— Between 11 and 12. I walk to the Capitol and attend at the Meeting of the House— It continues in Session from 3 to 4. P.M. I then walk home and dine, and after an hour of relaxation, take hot rice milk at tea time and spend the remainder of the Evening at cards, or in my chamber, writing— The succession of severe cold days deprives me of my morning writing hours and threatens another irretrievable breach in my Diary.

Year— The year 1836. has been a year of some vicissitude in my public life, and in my private concerns—strewed with roses, and beset with thorns; for the results of which, I bow in grateful homage to the Disposer of all Events— A year of severe trials, which I have sustained without sinking, by the aid of a merciful protector, but which in the course of Nature I cannot expect to sustain me much longer— The year began by a desperate and furious, yet insidious and crafty onset upon my character, by Daniel Webster in the form of a Speech in the Senate on the 14th. of January—published with great flourishes of trumpets in the National Intelligencer of the 18th— I answered by the offer of a Resolution of enquiry, and a Speech on the 22d. of the same Month; it demolished the Speech of Webster; drove him from the field, and whip’d him and his party into the rank of file of the Nation, in the quarrel with the French king—but it opened upon me the whole pack of the Presidential opposition candidates, and their abettors, in and out of Congress, who would have sunk me into perdition temporal and eternal, if they had had the power— I weathered this storm, and was re-elected to the next Congress without formal opposition, but almost without whig votes— The delivery of the Eulogy upon President Madison was the principal incident of the year—and was successful— I have to bless the giver of all good for improved health not only my own, but that of my dearest friend.
